text: welcome to the developing leaders series
my name is Miriam McLemore former
corporate CIO at the coca-cola company
and now enterprise strategist with AWS
where I partner with leaders globally to
enable business transformation we have
invited leaders from around the world
and across industries to share their
insights on leadership vision strategy
and people development Shaun thank you
so much for being here today well thanks
for having me I would love to start our
conversation with a question about how
you select or identify new leaders you
know I think there's not one single way
to do it there's an leadership comes in
so many different forms what we look for
are people who sort of stand out whether
it's in product development in
operations and bring something a bit
unique to the table and on the technical
side we look for folks who want to
invest time in the people around them
that's really important because
technical leadership is all about
mentorship it's all about guiding teams
it's all about providing them support we
have a nice formal process with HR where
we sit down and think about our
employees and think about what the
future potential is and how we can track
them and how it can help them so along
with that do you have a reward system
that calls out kind of those what we
called in our business high potential
leaders you know we definitely identify
high potential leaders and pay attention
to them the technical leadership team
tries to clean itself to say how much
time and attention are we giving these
future leaders are we helping them grow
if they're not growing are we doing all
the right things so while the onus is
certainly on them to step up we hold
ourselves accountable for that so we
especially look at doing things like
rewarding them through new opportunities
rewarding them through rotation we're
worrying them through visibility
rewarding them by letting them come and
speak at industry events and encouraging
that so and so forth that's great
so along the way right you were I'm sure
high potential talent as well where
there's leaders that inspired you there
were and you know I think inspiration
comes again at many different levels and
I think the most important often under
some folks were the the peers peers
would often coach me on things that they
we're good at that I wasn't and I tried
to do the same for them you know one
that stands out was a very early leader
and I had the opportunity sit down with
her she was I want to say three levels
up for me in the organization at the
time and I was just a few years out of
school still learning the ropes sat down
with her shared everything I did told
her about all these great things and she
gave some strong feedback to my boss at
the time and the feedback was great it
was he's smart he's articulate
doesn't know when to shut up didn't
actually let me speak and that was a
huge lesson for me that I was able to
incorporate getting that opportunity get
that candid feedback yeah guided by it
and being thankful for it was really
powerful yeah so she was a female and
you know we often think about for my
leader and mentorship perspective it's
nice to have diversity of leaders can
you talk a little bit about Charles
views on getting that mix in the team
for these leaders yeah I would say for
Dow Jones especially diversity is a huge
area of focus and it's a area folks for
one simple reason our customers are
diverse and we want our product teams or
technology teams to reflect our our
members and our customers and it also
helps us bring diverse points of view
and when we're building products you
know you want to understand how your
customer base your membership base
thinks in terms of growing leaders we do
a couple things we're running a great
new program their CEO is sponsoring to
identify diverse leaders across every
level focused on giving them attention
and support and within our organization
you know we always sort of step back and
periodically look around and look at
teams and look at groups and say are we
are we developing if we could develop I
think we've done a pretty good job of it
I love that and you know so obviously a
technology leader and part of being a
big leader is having the awareness of
technology trends in an evolving space
right so how do you do the same for your
team and keep your your team abreast and
also your business right abreast of
technology changes I think for the team
and business it's a bit different for
the team it's really simple don't block
them from spending time on things
they're passionate about yes there's the
balance with
four bowls that are due this month for
you know the maybe the exciting or maybe
the frustrating project that just has to
get done right but encouraging them to
carve out time and I think what we found
works best for at this point is each
leader within the technology
organization or decides what canes to
keep with their teams right for me
that's one the second is I always
encourage my team to go and spend time
at conferences and mixing with their
peers inside and outside of the
organization and that's sharing it also
I think means a lot when engineers and
operations folks hear from their peer
sets what they've learned right so bit
of all of that you know the product
teams obviously they often know more
about what's happening than we do it
just depends on the tactic I think we
work hard to keep our our business line
leaders our CFO on our CEO informed
what's happening try to offer them
commentary we're encouraging our teams
to adopt tool sets like slack to share
information more consume obli right not
to flood everyone with email right
finding interesting articles and sharing
them taking that extra couple minutes a
day can make a huge difference it pays
back pretty pretty quickly I would say
famously you know at Amazon Jeff
believes in failure
mm-hmm you know in shareholder letters
right Amazon's the best place to fail
and so could you share what you've
learned in your philosophy around
failure for you and your team you know I
think the best failures are either the
ones you learn from or you feel you do
the right things I probably had a decent
number of them one that stood out to me
and and it you know how to do with
expectations my first job in product
management you know all I wanted to do
was show ever I could take this service
that was perceived relatively well and
take it to the next level grow it you
know build a bit of my career as a
product manager off it and you know
within two or three months I looked at
and realized it was actually
hemorrhaging money it hadn't been you
know I guess it hadn't been very
transparent about how it operated and it
didn't actually make a lot of sense to
make it continue running and I sort of
struggle with what to do I was like I
have to make this successful did not
know how with some support from some
mentors I realized the actual answer was
to declare it a failure and to really be
transparent about it and go and get line
management support to say how do we shut
this down
that takes some courage especially early
in your career may be as courageous may
be every day no other choice I'm not
quite sure back at the time I felt a
little courageous but but the key lesson
was learning
a position to present that how you know
not to cover it up right I'll not to try
to run away from the role but to take
ownership of it and do it gracefully to
make sure the customers were served by
were treated well and had an exit
strategy for it yep and you know that
was probably one of the hardest things I
did do to take something over I think I
was making my mark from it instead just
be like we're shutting it down yeah but
it was it turned out it turned out well
enough and has that served you well
leading teams that when failures happen
yeah I think the thing I pushed the most
to people when they have feathers or
challenges used to communicate them be
transparent about them ask for help
early you want to be able to go to your
management team to your stakeholders and
talk about what you're facing ask them
for their help and and tell them what
you think you should do don't go in with
thing I don't know what to do right the
solution right but it doesn't if you
perfectly baked right and I think that's
the lesson I took away from that first
early failure and I think it's one that
has served me well and hopefully serve
the people I've coached and mentored
well as well that's great a great
example so can you tell me about the
most exciting project that you have
going I think my answer is different
every week which is probably a testament
to the fact that I get to work a lot of
fun things which I love that's great the
one probably that's top of mind this
week not everyone think was exciting but
I'm a little excited by it is around
cloud security we are spending a ton of
time looking at ways to automate a lot
of the things that we do and it's been

world cross that with our cloud and
DevOps teams and see them all sort of

balance we even sort of borrowing
